coredata.dc:title: Solute-solvent exciplexes as the source of anomalous fluorescence from 4-N,N-dimethylamino-ethylbenzoate in 1,4-dioxane and in polar solvents
coredata.dc:creator: Visser, Robert J.
Weisenborn, Petra C.M.
Varma, Cyril A.G.O.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The behaviour of 4-N,N-dimethylamino-ethylbenzoate in its lowest electronically excited singlet and triplet states in solutions in apolar and polar solvents has been investigated by measuring the lifetime and quantum yield of the fluorescence, quantum yield of the triplet state and transient dielectric loss induced by laser pulse excitation. The major conclusion is that the anomalous fluorescence of the compound in 1,4-dioxane and in polar solvents is emitted by solute-solvent exciplexes. The previously reported anomalous fluorescence of the compound in alkanes has not been observed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 113, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januari 1985 SOLUTE-SOLVENT EXCIPLEXES AS THE SOURCE OF ANOMALOUS FLUORESCENCE FROM 4-N,N-DMETHYLAMINO-ETHYLBENZOATE EM 1,4-DIOXANE AND IN POLAR SOLVENTS Robert J. VISSER, Petra C.M. WEISENBORN and Cyril A.G 0. VARMA Department of (chemistry, dorlaeus Laboratories, University of Leyden, P.O. Box 9502. 2300 RA Ley Sen. The Netherlands Received 16 August 1984;in final form 28 November 1984 The behaviour of4-N,N-diniethylaniino-ethylbenzoate in its lowest electronically excited singlet and triplet states in solutions in apolai and polar solvents has been investigated by measuring the lifetime and quantum yield of the fluorescence, quantum yield of the triplet state and transient dielectric loss induced by laser pulse excitation. The major conclusion is that the anomalous fluorescence of the compound in 1,4-dioxane and in polar solvents is emitted by solute- solvent exdplexcs. The previously reported anomalous fluorescence of the compound in alkanes has not been observed. 1. Introduction 4-N,N-dimethylamino-benzonitrile (DMABN) [1] in polar solvents is known to exhibit a fluorescence band with an extremely large red-shift with respect to the first electronic absorption band. We have been able to show that the large red-shift of the fluorescence of DMABN in polar solvents arises because the emis- sion comes from 1: 1 solute—solvent exciplexes [2—5]. It appears that these exciplexes are not formed due to long-range solute—solvent interactions alone, but that the formation requires a specific interaction involving the overlap of electronic wavefunctions of the consti- tuents. In the particular case of DMABN the specific interaction arises when lone-pair orbitalsofthe solvent and of the ammo nitrogen atom of the solute overlap. From this point of view an anomalously Stokes-shifted fluorescence is not expected from solutions of DMABN and related compounds in saturated hydro- carbons- However, a long-wavelength fluorescence band of 4-N.N-dimethylanuno-ethylbenzoate (DMAEB, fig. 1) in a number of alkanes at 370 nm has recently been reported [6]. The emission in the region of this band is strong in the temperature range between 250 and 140 K and disappears at77K. This behaviour has been attributed to the formation of an emissive twisted 330 Fig 1- Structural formula of 4-N,N-diinethylanuno-ethylben- zoate. intramolecular charge-transfer state (TICT) [7] in which the dimethylamino group is perpendicular to the phenyl ring. In the report just mentioned the author suggests that the fluorescence of DMABN in 3-methylpentane is a superposition of the emission from such a TICT state and from the excited molecule widi the planar conformation. The suggestion is based on the reduction of the width of the fluorescence band of the solution by 300 cm"1 upon lowering the temperature from 293 to 77 K. Since the formation of an emissive TICT state is thought to offer an alternative explanation [7] of the anomalous fluorescence of DMABN in polar solvents, we have reinvestigated the fluorescence of DMAEB. We report results and conclusions obtained from a study of the influence of temperature on the fluores- cence, from a study of the lifetime of the fluorescence 0 OG9-2614/85/S 03.30 © EIsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 113, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januari 1985 and the triplet quantum yield of solutions in a number of solvents and from measurements of the photo-in- duced transient dielectric loss of solutions in cyclo- hexane and in 1,4-dioxane. 2. Experimental 4-N,N-dimethylammo-ethylbenzoate(DMAEB) (Aldnch) was purified by recrystallization from ethanol and subsequent sublimation. The compound was identified by means of IR and NMR spectroscopy. The UV absorption and emission spectra did not change as a result of the purification. Spectrograde quality solvents •'-n'e been used. Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Hitachi— Perkin—Elmel HPF2A spectrofluorinieter and have been correct id for instrumental distortions [2]. Quinine sulfate in 1 N sulfiric acid ($? = 0-55) was used as the standard in the determination of fluor- escence quantum yields [4]. The reported fluorescence quantum yields have been corrected for the differen- ces between the refractive index of the standard solu- tion and that of the sample solutions. Fluorescence spectra of solutions at low temperature were obtained by two different methods. In the first method the sa..ipi» 'T rapidly immersed in liquid nitrogen or in mixtures ofcarbondioxide and 2-methyl-THF or ethanol contained in a Dewar vessel provided with optical windows- In this manner the sample attains the final temperature in a minute. In the second method the sample reaches the final temperature gradually over a penod of about 30 min in an optical cryostat. The temperature of the sample was determined with a thermocouple inserted in the solution. The methods used to detennine triplet quantum yields and fluorescence lifetimes have been reported [4]. The techniques used to measure photo-induced transient dielectric loss and dielectric loss ofunexcited solutions has also been described [5,8]. 3. Results and discussion The fluorescence spectra of DMAEB in a mixture of methylcyclohexane and methylcyclopentane (1:1 vol), at a number of temperatures, were recorded. The ,nMCH/MCP(1:1) IF lO^O'lcm"1] Fig. 2. Fluorescence spectra of DMAEB in methylcyclohexane/ rnethylcyclopentane (1:1, vol). ——, 295 K; ——, 77 K. two methods of cooling the solution lead, for each temperature, to identical spectra. This indicates that there is no aggregation of solute molecules taldng place upon cooling. The spectra of the solution at 295 K: and at 77 K are shown in fig. 2. The width of the fluorescence band is listed in t-«ble 1 for a number of temperatures. Cooling has httle or no effect on the width except below the glass transition tempera- ture at 77 K. We have not been able to observe the previously reported [6] broadening of the fluorescence band with decreasing temperature in the range 150 < T < 293 K. The width of the band for the glassy solution is noticeably smaller than for the liquid solu- Table 1 Width of the fluorescence band of DMAEB in methylcyclo- hexane/methylcyclopeBtane (1:1 vol) at a number of temperatures Temp. Halfwidth of the (K) fluorescence band (fwhm) (cm"1) 293 3800 203 3800 185 3900 77 3100 331 Volume 113, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januari 1985 tion- This is due in part to the narrower Boltzmann distribution of conformations of ground-state solute molecules and in part to the restriction on confonra- tional relaxation of the excited solute in the rigid matrix- We have also not been able to find the pre- viously reported [6] structure in the long-wavelength edge of the spectrum for 150 K which has been of- fered as evidence for two emitting species. When a solution ofDMAEB in cyclohexane con- tains a low concentration of a polar solvent P, the short-wavelength fluorescence FM is less intense than in the absence of P and the solution shows an additio- nal fluorescence band F^ around 23000 cm""1- This behaviour is shown in fig- 3 for the particular choice ofpropionitrile for P. The total fluorescence spectrum in fig. 3 may be decomposed in a band F^ and a band F^ [2]. The ratio R sJCF^^CFiq) of the peak heights Z(F^) and-f(F^), of the bands F^ and F^ respectively, is proportional to the concentration Cp ofF, i.e..R =fcgCp- This is illustrated by the insert in fig. 3. In table 2 we list values offcp determined with different choices of P. The quenching of the normal fluorescence F^ of DMAEB by P obeys Stem—Volmer kinetics. The Stem—Volmer plot yields the product kyTQ of the rate constant ky for quenching and the unperturbed fluorescence lifetime TQ. Using the lifetime Tn = 1.0 ns, measured for a solution in cyclohexane, the values ka in table 2 are found. For all three P, the value of kq is smaller than expected for the diffusion-limited reaction rate k^. We estimate k^ = 1-5 X 1010 dm3 mol"1 s"1 for a diffusion-controlled reaction of acetonitrile in cyclohexane. The established linear relation-R =ksCy and the linear Stem—Volrner plot for the quenching of F]^ by P are evidence for the formation of 1 - 1 exciplexes between P and DMAEB in its first excited electronic singlet state. Exciplexes ofP and DMAEB or its den- 18 20 22 2t 26 28 30 32 lO^O-lcm"1! Fig- 3. The effect or the addition of propionil-rilc on the fluorescence spectrum of a. solution ofDMAEB in cyclo- bexane The insert shows the linear dependence of the ratio HJFj^fICFti) on the concentration of added propionitnie. vatives with their fluorescence strongly shifted to the red of the band FJ|] are observed under the same conditions as in the case ofDMABN or its derivatives, namely when P has a loose pair of electrons and the —N—(€113)2 group is not inhibited to achieve an orientation perpendicular to the phenyl ling. This is illustrated by the fact that the non-dipolar compound 1,4-dioxane forms such emissive exciplexes with DMAEB and by the fact [9] that l-ethylindoline-5- carboxylic-ethyl esters do not show anomalous fluorescence in polar solvents- Table 2 Quenching of the normal fluorescence F^] of DMAEB by molecules P accompanied by growth of the anomalous fluorescence FA- ky is the bimolecular rate constant for quenching, TO is the unperturbed lifetime of FN and -/(FA)/.WN) = k^Cp P *qfn (dm3 mol~1) Aq (dm3 mol-1 s~1) fce (dm3 mol""1) 1,4-dioxane propioiutrile acetonitrile 0.17 5.57 629 1.7 X 5 6X 6.3 X lO" 109 109 0.17 1.78 1 99 332 Volume 113, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januari 1985 t Fig. 4. The fluorescence spectrum of DMAEB in 1,4-dioxane. ——, fluorescence spectrum as observed; ———, decomposition of the fluorescence spectrum in two bands: Fg with a maximum at 29000 cm"1 and F^. with a maximum at 23500 cm"1. Fig. 4 illustrates that the solution of DMAEB in 1,4-dioxane exhibits a fluorescence band in the wave- length region where the normal fluorescence F^ of the solution in cyclohexane appears. In order to dis- tinguish this band from F^ we will denote it by Fg- Both the fluorescence Fg and FA of the solution in 1,4-di^xane decay mono-exponentially with lifetimes Tp(E) and Tp(A) respectively- It turns out that TpCE) = Tp(A) = 6.5 ns Because the lifetime of state S^(N) obtained from the decay of the fluorescence FJ^ of the solution in cyclohexane is 1.0 ns, the fluorescence Fg must arise from a state other than S^(N). We suggest that the fluorescence Fg is emitted by solute- solvent exciplexes ^i in which the N—(?3)^ group of the solute is coplanar with the phenyl ring and that Fy^ is emitted by exciplexes £3 with the N—(0113)2 perpendicular to the ring. Evidence for the formation of emissive solute—solvent exciplexes of type ^i has been provided previously for 1-methyl- S,(N) 1.0ns k,COj [ Decay Products Tp(N) = Decay ProducLe (k^ +,k_) > > 1^(1) > k^(2) Scheme 1. 6-cyano-l,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline in 1,4-dioxane [5]. In order to account for the equality Tp(E) = Tp(A) we suggest that after state Si(N) is converted to EI a thermal equilibrium between ^J and ^3 is established in a time Tgq which is short compared to their lifetimes and also short compared to th'^ response time of the detection system, i.e. T^n < 100 ps, and we also suggest that ^^ decays much faster tuan ^^ which means that the lifetime o. the equL'.orium is determined by the decay of ^E^ These suggestions are summarized in scheme 1 - Table 3 contains the quantum yields and lifetimes of normal and anomalous fluorescence, the quantum yield ofintersystem crossing for solutions of DMAEB in cyclohexane, 1.4-dioxane and propioiutrile. We have determined a quantum yield of 0.29 for the normal fluorescence of DMAEB in cyclohexane. This value is larger than reported previously [6]. Table 3 also contains the decay rate constants for the solution in cyclohexane determined according to scheme 2. (3) Using relation (3) we find that the fraction of primary excited molecules converted to the exciplex IE^ is larger than 0.73 and 0.95 for the solutions in 1,4-dioxane and propionitrile respectively. Although a precise calculation offep(l), Apt2)' ^iscW and *I5cCO cannot be performed, some general conclusions concerning them may be drawn -when we compare Tp, ^p and ^&p for cyclohexane and 1,4-dioxane as solvent. The relations Tp(A) ^ Tp(N) and ^p(l) + <£p(2) < ^>pCN) lead to the conclusion kyfN) §> A:p(l) > fcp(2). The increase in total triplet-state quantum yield of DMAEB from 0.14 in cyclohexane to 0.52 in 1.4-dioxane is a consequence of the long radiative lifetime of ^-E| and ^E^ in 1,4-dioxane which counter- acts the reduction of the rate of intersystem crossing caused by exciplex formation. We have studied the transient change in the dielec- tric loss at microwave frequencies in solutions of DMAEB in apolar solvents induced by pulse laser ex- citation of the solute. The dielectric loss arises from rotational motion of dipolar solute molecules. The dielectric loss factor e" is related to the electrical conductivity a by a = wene (4) in which cis is the angular frequency of the microwave field and EQ is the permittivity of vacuum [11]. The transient change in a is given by A(7(f) = [(t^)2^?^] S N^t) ^ , (5) JLf'SjES 0 334 Volume 113, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januari 1985 Table 4 Results obtained from measuremen t of the pulsed laser-induced transient dielectric loss of solutions of DMAEB. (8) where T^is the dielectric relaxation time of the Zth species- In table 4 values of OQ are given for the solu- tions in cyclohexane and in 1,4-dioxane. The values of S2^ in table 4 have been evaluated from the measured temporal profile of Ao(r) in a manner de- scribed previously [5.8]- In the case of the solution in eyclohexane we have as excited species only bare solute molecules in either the state Si(N) or To(N). The molecular conforma- tion of DMAEB in the state S^(N) is not very different from the ground-state conformation. We assume that this is also true for the lowest excited state T()(N)- We therefore assume that the dielectric relaxation times of DMAEB in the states Si(N) or To(N) are equal to T^Q. The magnitude of the ground-state dipole moment fiQ is estimated to be 12-5 X 10~30 C m, based on the experimental value fly = 10.9 X 10-30 C m in the case of 4-amino-ethylbenzoate [12]. With tne estimated value of^o a dielectric relaxation time T^ of 64 and 83 ps is obtained for the solutions in cyclohexane and 1,4-dioxanc respectively. This leads to the dipole moments given in table 4. The dipole moment iu(Tg) is smaller than Ai(Sj). This phenomenon, which was also observed for solutions ofDMABN and its deriva- tives in cyclohexane [5], should be attributed to a different electronic configuration in the states SJ(N) and To(N). As pointed out above, the number of molecules in the state S^fN) in 1,4-dioxane as solvent are all con- verted to either ^^ or ^^ type exciplexes. Conse- quently there is no contribution to Ac(r) from molecules in Si(N). Because ^^ and ^-E-^ both decay mono-exponentially with a lifetime Tpa = 6.5 r-s, their contributions to Aa(t) may be grouped to a single term ^(^E) in the rhs ofeq. (5). The values of J2(-^E^) and Sl^-E^) cannot be obtained separately from n^E). However, we may draw a conclusion from the fact that the value of Sl (S^) is an order of magnitude larger than Si^E) The change in viscosity between cyclohexane and 1,4-dioxane leads to a reduction of S2(Si) of the molecules of only a factor 1.4- We therefore conclude that the dipole moment of the exciplexes ^^ and ^^ are much smaller than the dipole moment of the excited smglet state of the bare molecule and that the dielectric relaxation time of the exciplexes is larger than T^Q of the bare solute m 1,4-dioxane. The dielectric loss due to the excited triplet state is not influenced as much by the forma- tion of exciplexes with 1,4-dioxane as is that of the excited smglet state. The value of I^E) is smaller than S2(To) by a factor of only two. This suggests that triplet-state exciplexes formed by intersystem crossing from ^^ or ^5 are in thermal equilibrium with the triplet state of the bare solute. In the equi- librium only a small part of the triplei-state molecules consist of exciplexes. 335 Volume 113. number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 Januanl985 References [1] E. Lippert, W. LQder and H. head.ce:title: Solute-solvent exciplexes as the source of anomalous fluorescence from 4-N,N-dimethylamino-ethylbenzoate in 1,4-dioxane and in polar solvents

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, Gorlaeus Laboratories, University of Leyden, P.O. Box 9502, 2300 RA Leyden, The Netherlands

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The behaviour of 4-N,N-dimethylamino-ethylbenzoate in its lowest electronically excited singlet and triplet states in solutions in apolar and polar solvents has been investigated by measuring the lifetime and quantum yield of the fluorescence, quantum yield of the triplet state and transient dielectric loss induced by laser pulse excitation. The major conclusion is that the anomalous fluorescence of the compound in 1,4-dioxane and in polar solvents is emitted by solute-solvent exciplexes. The previously reported anomalous fluorescence of the compound in alkanes has not been observed.
